displayed_text: Patient: Get it done. Come on C__, come on over here. Doctor: She’s out of here. Patient: You know what man. Doctor: Here’s your starter kit. Patient: What is this?. Doctor: There’s some information for you about what this medicine is. And this medicine so see… no wait (pages turning) Patient: Mm, Hmm. Doctor: There’s only one, fatigue. Patient: Fatigue, okay. Doctor: Then less common there’s a whole bunch of them. Patient: Right. Doctor: Back pain, diarrhea, flashes, edema. So it’s everything that you had last…

Family Member: I wanted, I want your input, uh but we couldn’t just give him that - because he is all at that level of three injections of testosterone, he’s a perfect candidate just for that immune thing just to see? (Beeping) Doctor: Well, the immune thing is normally I, I don’t. We’re not allowed to give anything unless it’s in a disease where it’s been approved- Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: because the cost is so very high, the hospital won’t let us do anything. So normally what we have to do is go through the insurance company, tell them what we wanted to do, they deny it, you write letters. So it’s not something that I can just do it tomorrow. Family Member: So you can’t ask-? Doctor: Now you, you know, who have, you’re a person of means, that maybe you could just pay for it, but I haven’t really, I don’t know what the avenue is to do that. (Laughs) Family Member: Well- Patient: Give, give that some thought, too. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Like maybe it’s, if you think it is worthwhile doing since I’m already trying with the testosterone to do it, uh. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You can follow a number of avenues. Doctor: I could ask the pharmacist if there’s a way that, you know, if the patient could actually just pay for it themselves and just get it.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But you know I never just do the standard routine anything. (Laughs) Patient: I been here long enough, I just, I am not new here. Doctor: Yes. So there is uh you know the trial is two-thirds of the people get vitamin C, Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: high dose. So this stuff comes out of Hopkins you know from a special company. It took us forever to do it. But the grade of vitamin C is great. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Because they’re not all the same. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so you always fuss about that. Because there’s other people giving high-dose vitamin C Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but you can’t guarantee the product.

Patient: The Erlida? Doctor: The Erlida, yeah. Patient: Two weeks ago I think. Doctor: Two weeks. Okay. Patient: Well, let's see now. Family Member 1: When you came last week? No? Patient: No, I think was the week before and you told me to stop. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Right. I think it's been at least two weeks. Patient: Yeah, at least two weeks. Doctor: Hopefully, it'll you know, flush out some more slowly get better. You know, the more natural thing you should ask her. She's gonna be the expert, you know, like melatonin. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Things like that. Family Member 1: He does try them.

Family Member: It was very interesting. And we was laughing because- Doctor: What cities did you go to in South Africa? Did you visit any cities or-? Patient: We was all over the place. Family Member: Um hum. We was in Cape Town, Johannesburg, these little towns. Patient: Swaziland. Family Member: Swaziland. Patient: Zululand. Hazyview. Family Member: There, we had to cross the border. And so we had to go and show your passport, get stamped, or whatever, and go back across the border. Doctor: To Swaziland? Is that a-? Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That’s like one of those little countries that’s inside of some? Patient: Um hum. Yeah.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know? We, we have a look now which is not a super early look but it still is within, you know, a few weeks of finishing. Sometimes when times goes on, then, you know, you’ll have new stuff, but- Family Member: So no, no, no, uh, MRIs in order right now? Doctor: No. Unless you’re telling me you’re worse. Family Member: Well, he’s got, he’s in pain, but that might be sciatic. He don’t know. Patient: No. Doctor: Man, it’s always your darn back. Family Member: Well, hip and leg. Doctor: Is it the hip and leg? Patient: Well, it’s, it like radiates from here down. Family Member: The pelvis down. Doctor: Uh, refresh my memory. Have we ever MRI’d that?

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, there’s a, there’s a couple of trials that are in the works that might be specifically suited for you Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because of this mutation. Patient: So, we’re not, not doing standard of care. Doctor: Right. Patient: Pat We’re looking at potent—very, uh, plausibly potential choices down the road. Doctor: Yes. Patient: And, and, and so at this point --- Doctor: I mean, including standard of care. So, standard of care is always our baseline. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then we, you know, I could just, my description will be, “here’s what standard of care does, here’s what we expect.”

Patient: Okay. Doctor: It may potentially lessen the side effects if you do it that way without the Lupron at the same time. Patient: Yeah, yeah. For some reason the Lupron, that just knocks me out. For some reason I forget a lot of things, hallucination; I get a Doctor: Great, now when would you like to check the next PSA level and when would you like to do it? Patient: Now next PSA, now did you place an order for mine? Doctor: I did. Patient: Okay, because when I went there they said they didn’t see it. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And I had to call in and they faxed it. Doctor: Okay. I will do two things today. When I place the prescription I will send electronically and then I will also print the actual paper prescription. Patient: Okay. Uh huh. Doctor: And hand it to you. That should be the backup.

Patient: I threw up times. I have Doctor: I think we should refer him to GI because I really don’t know what uh… Patient: What? Doctor: I have no idea. I’ve never seen that. Patient: Yeah me either. Doctor: And we can’t see it on the CAT scan either. So I don’t know what to make of it. Patient: What? Doctor: We’ll, we’ll talk to the radiologist. Patient: Wait a minute, wait a minute Dr. B____, you got me scared and everything. If I can’t see it on the CAT scan. Doctor: Why are you scared? Patient: I’m not well well God is good. Doctor: It’s a good thing. Patient: Yes.

Patient: To go to Cornell. Doctor: Cornell or UCLA, so, yeah. Patient: Well, I guess I would ask you, if possible, to check out both avenues. I’d want to see which one. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I mean my interest, our interest, is just to stop this stuff from growing. It seems to be growing at a consistent pace. I don’t know if it’s slow, fast, or whatever, but it’s not stopping. And do you think that this, this sort of, from what you know from this, from the, you know PSMA, that would have a real uh opportunity to stop the growth? Doctor: Yeah. I think from the data they published, it actually looks really good, uh, and- Patient: If it’s so good, why don’t they, why does it take so long in the U.S. then to get these? Doctor: So, in Germany, and Australia, I know they’re also doing it in Australia. I know it’s a little farther for you- Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Uh in Germany they have a law that if the doctor thinks something is beneficial it doesn’t have to be you know like you know in America, FDA approved. So the FDA, the bar is show me it makes people live longer. It’s a pretty high bar. Because that requires a lot of patients, a lot time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but at the end of the day, you feel really confident that what I’m giving you could help.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 10 years (5 years but le: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 10 years (5 years but less than 10 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::strongly agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: In three months I’ll get another CAT scan? Doctor: Yes. Patient: But not bone scan? Doctor: No I don’t think we need it unless anything changes with your surgery and all the symptoms – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - and of course if any of that changes, don’t wait the three months. I need to know before that of course. Patient: Yeah right. Family Member: Okay, getting back to the bone scan. Doctor: Yes. Family Member: What about osteoporosis? Is that showing up? Something we need to be concerned about? Doctor: No bone scan typically doesn’t show up. Family Member: Oh, okay.

Family Member: Hm Hmm. Doctor: you can sorta plan it out. So, the week that’s the scariest is if you get your chemo and Christmas and all those people are there seven to ten days after, that’s dangerous. Healthcare Professional: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Okay, but, if it’s the twenty, you know the eighteenth day of the cycle… Patient: So, apply the no-fly rule. Doctor: ‘Cuz again if Healthcare Professional: Yes. Doctor: his counts are already up and ready for the next cycle, that’s the safest. Family Member: Oh, got it. Got it. Yep, I see that. I see that. Math makes sense. Yep. Family Member: Now, I just have to remember it. (pause) Patient: We’ll see, we’ll just try to make it happen. We’ll just schedule it out. Family Member: Mmm. I think we might go with the artificial, artificial tree. Aren’t we glad we

Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Right. Healthcare Professional: Alright. Doctor: So let’s do that, see how you do and then we’ll switch, we’ll add the sleeping pill. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay because too many changes if the pills don’t match well together. Patient: Well I wouldn’t take them all at one time nowhere, if I take my other pill then I wait another hour and then I take that. Doctor: Okay. Well you definitely cannot take the Ambien and the Restoril together. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Are you going to remember that? Patient: Don’t take the Ambien and the who again?
